response.answer_text: 4.902806391817x10^12. About 5 trillion or about 1/4 of the national debt in dollars. You didn’t specify what you needed the info for and I’m not sure I understand your question in the first place. Yes, it’s a huge number by everyday standards and represents about 73% of the number of miles in a light year. It could be roughly the number of bacteria on a couple hundred dog turds over time. We use a formula N(t) =N(0)e^(kt) with specific parameters but generally the accuracy past 3 or 4 decimal places is questionable at best. But size is relative. On the other hand if you consider a number such as a nonillion (10^30), your number would be microscopic. Consider a Coulomb of electrical charge…6.24x10^18 electrons (or protons).
